description: The root cause of the critical vulnerabilities detailed in the November 2024 Patch Tuesday update stems from multiple exploitation paths, primarily involving elevation of privilege and spoofing vulnerabilities. One significant issue is an elevation of privilege vulnerability in Windows Task Scheduler (CVE-2024-49039), impacting Windows 10 and later OS editions, rated 'important' with a CVSS score of 8.8. This vulnerability allows attackers to run specially crafted applications to elevate privileges on affected systems. Another notable cause is CVE-2024-43451, a spoofing vulnerability in NTLM, allowing attackers to capture NTLMv2 authentication credentials with minimal user interaction. Furthermore, CVE-2024-49019, affecting Active Directory Certificate Services, can lead to unauthorized domain administrator access and has been publicly disclosed. Lastly, vulnerabilities like CVE-2024-49040 in Microsoft Exchange Server and CVE-2024-5535 involving OpenSSL libraries in Microsoft Defender illustrate the breadth of exploitable vulnerabilities, warranting immediate patching and attention from administrators.
